body: Update
want to change in master branch.

Bumps [lodash](https://github.com/lodash/lodash) from 4.17.11 to 4.17.19.

You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot use these labels` will set the current labels as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `@dependabot use these reviewers` will set the current reviewers as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `@dependabot use these assignees` will set the current assignees as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `@dependabot use this milestone` will set the current milestone as the default for future PRs for this repo and language You can disable automated security fix PRs for this repo from the [Security Alerts page](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/network/alerts).
This uses patches provided by the community in #577 and the dependabot fixes from #588. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/adam-p/markdown-here/592)
The CommonMark spec says ordered lists can start with any arbitrary value: <https://spec.commonmark.org/0.29/#start-number> this PR allows that in Markdown Here.

Bumps [lodash](https://github.com/lodash/lodash) from 4.17.11 to 4.17.15.

contribute

Closed Previous Pull request for completeness

- CSS for the preference dialogs has moved
- NsISupportsString in setComplexValue() has been dropped in favour of setStringPref()
- Thunderbird 60 refusing explicit declaration of option type 1 in install.rdf

In Thunderbird 60 the options dialogue shows transparent. 

Copied this stylesheet reference from the Awesome auto archive project: `CSS for the preference dialogs has moved from Mozilla core to Thunderbird in TB59`

elem.ownerDocument.location is about:blank so I used
elem.ownerDocument.URL instead.

Hi Adam,

This pull request adds a Google Chrome badge to indicate to the user whether their selection will be rendered or unrendered. This was mentioned in Issue #258 (Make toggle button more state-aware).

There was an earlier pull request that had messy commits (PR #315 ). This contains the same content but tidier.

Here's a snippet of the badge:

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5429930/11435643/78848f84-9491-11e5-8c2e-94cdfbfd8f62.png)
## Refactor changes

In the `markdown-here.js` file, we pulled out some code inside `markdownHere` and put it into a new function `getMarkdownRenderObject` so that we could reuse it. You'll see there's a another new function called `selectionContainsRenderedMarkdown` that needed the same code.

Hi Adam,

I was tired of forgetting to render my Markdown emails in Fastmail, and decided to see if I could extend your excellent forgot-to-render check to the Fastmail compose interface. (Issue #317)

It almost-but-not-quite works in this initial PR.  The event listeners are set up and work properly, both for clicking the **Send** button and for using the send hotkeys (which are the same in Fastmail as Gmail).  The script correctly catches and prevents sending an unrendered email when I click **Send**.  But if I use the ⌘+Enter hotkey, the email is sent _and then_ Markdown Here opens the forgot to render prompt.  It seems that `eatEvent()` is not eating the hotkey send action.

I have no prior experience with JavaScript, so I thought I would stop here and ask you for guidance.  In fact, this is also my first submission to an open source project.

Michael

Hi Adam,

I'm a Computer Engineering student from UBC and I just wanted to say thank you for contributing Markdown Here. I started using MDH this semester for taking notes in my classes with Evernote and it's been an incredible tool. Having Markdown has made notetaking for my programming-related classes much more natural - it feels like I'm just writing documentation for a lecture!

For my Software Engineering class, we have a project where we make a contribution to an open source project on GitHub. I convinced my group to contribute to yours. We picked Enhancement #258 as a suitable starting point for the codebase.

This is the work we have so far, and we've decided to pull request it to you for feedback if we're going in the right direction. We're in the process of learning the mocha framework so we can add tests, you'll see them added to this pull request in a day or so. We also aren't sure what direction we should take for Firefox and were hoping to get some ideas from you.

Here is a picture of the "Render Available" badge, which indicates to the user that there is Markdown ready to be rendered:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5429930/11435643/78848f84-9491-11e5-8c2e-94cdfbfd8f62.png)

I just started work on the new options page. This is just a quick non-functional mockup of the idea I have in mind. I just wanted to get some opinion on this thing, just to be sure I'm not making something that I'll have to trash later...

While, I realize that I forgot about the translation-related stuff in the current state of the page, it should be trivial to add, given that I reuse the original text, which I obivously intend to.

I just wanted to ask if it is OK if I re-arrange the files used by options.html so that the folder is more organized. (Someone will need to run :eyes: to make sure I don't break something...)

/cc @rafegoldberg @adam-p
Comments where placed in reverse in 16393e7.

This (tiny) PR addresses #219, however whether you merge is at your discretion because of the behaviour I noticed when testing:
- When composing a new mail in gmail, the signature is inserted within a DOM element that has the `gmail_signature` class. The couple of lines I've added will detect the signature & skip the DOM recursion.
- After saving the mail as a draft and closing your browser tab, all of the classes on the email's markup are lost. As such, **when returning to an old draft from a previous browsing session, this method of signature detection fails**.

I'm therefore in two minds as to whether this would be a beneficial thing; on the one hand, custom gmail signatures that weren't currently working will work without the need to prefix with `--`, but on the other, users may experience this sort of signature being parsed as markdown intermittently, which might be more confusing than the previous consistent inclusion.

Similar to `issue #69`, the false hyperlinks are assigned when rendering **reflink** and **no link** which are automatically hyperlinked by browser at editing. This problem won't happen in plain text mode. ##### Syndromes ``` [label]: http://example.com ``` will be rendered into ``` [label]: http://example.com ``` --- ``` [label]: http://example.com ``` will be rendered into ``` [label]: http://example.com ``` ##### Fix Fix is done by adding the pattern of link reference to the regex in function _convertHTMLtoMarkdown_ .
added bool val to accept the [Google Inbox](http://www.google.com/inbox/)
Translation to Chinese added.
Added reference to the "Tips and Tricks" section to the main README.md
